background: Jake and Eleanor seek marriage counseling after Jake's heart attack, attributing stress to their unhappy marriage.
pre_reasoning: Many people experience even greater change in their depression when they do “talk therapy” as well as medications. The therapist inquires about the client's perception of positive change attributed to medication versus self-initiated changes in depression.

dialog.text: [Invariably, the client assigns at least a small percentage to his own efforts toward change in therapy and in his daily living.]
dialog.observation: Client acknowledges personal efforts in therapy and daily life.

dialog.text: So, let’s just focus on that part of you and your experience that you have some control over—that part of the changes you say is not the medicine. What’s our next step regarding your depression, KVTU in that area? 'PMMPX VQ RVFTUJPOT How do you see that as being under your control? How have you influenced that, on purpose? What does that say about your ability to influence part of your depression?
dialog.reasoning: Therapist guides client to explore areas of control and influence over their depression.

post_reasoning:
A Case Example
Jake and Eleanor contacted me for marriage counseling recently. Jake had suffered a heart attack 8 weeks prior to our first session, and they related that a lot of the stress that “caused” his heart attack came from their unhappy marriage. Unbeknownst to me, Jake had an appointment with his cardiologist between the second and third marital therapy sessions and began taking an antidepressant. When he told me, I inquired about his decision, and he informed me that he had already been experiencing the negative side effects.
